thread.title: Aust bonds flatten after volatile week
thread.title_full: Aust bonds flatten after volatile week

title: Aust bonds flatten after volatile week
text:
Mon, Aug 17, 2015, 9:43 AM AEST - Australia Markets open in 17 mins. Aust bonds flatten after volatile week AAP â€“ 32 minutes ago Print 
The Australian bond market is stabilising after last week's large Chinese currency devaluations caused some volatility. 
Bond markets rallied early last week after China started to devalue the yuan on Tuesday but then handed back the gains later in the week. 
St George senior economist Jo Horton said US and Australian bond markets had flattened out after an up-and-down week. 
"US government bond yields were little changed on Friday night, lifting slightly as upbeat US economic data left expectations of the US Federal Reserve (monetary policy) tightening intact," she said. 
The main event for financial markets this week will be the release of the minutes of the US Federal Reserve's July policy meeting, due early on Thursday morning, Australian time. 
Traders will be looking for any hints of when the Fed will make its first interest rate rise in nine year. 
At 0830 AEST on Monday, the September 2015 10-year bond futures contract was trading at 97.185 (implying a yield of 2.815 per cent), level with the local close on Friday. 
The September 2015 three-year bond futures contract was at 98.020 (1.980 per cent), slightly down from 98.030 (1.970 per cent). 
KEY MOVEMENTS: 
* CGS 5.5pct Jan 2018, 1.939pct, from 1.941pct on Friday 
* CGS 4.25pct April 2026, 2.867pct, from 2.868pct 
Sydney Futures Exchange prices: 
* September 2015 bill futures, 97.890, unchanged 
* December 2015 bill futures, 97.930, unchanged 
(*Closes taken at 1630 AEST previous local session) 
Source: IRESS
